captions.text:
Hi there,
We're still in Japan.
Tonight we're going to treat ourselves
to a traditional Japanese fugu feast.
Fugu is well-known as *the* lethally poisonous Japanese fish
for example the emperor is not allowed to eat it
for the fear of accidental poisoning.
We, however, fear not,
and we're going to have one of those swimming little guys
for dinner tonight.
As a starter we've got here cooked fugu skin,
let's try it.
Mmm, very delicate.
The toxin present in fugu paralyzes the muscles.
If the chef makes a mistake
you start to suffocate
and eventually die of asphyxiation.
This is fugu sashimi.
Sliced very thinly, very delicate
the taste is so subtle it's barely even there,
but because the cuts are so fine, it's really a pleasure to eat.
It's not that those fugu restaurants are places of doom
with customers constantly being rushed to an emergency room.
It's a really rare thing to happen for somebody to get poisoned.
This is fugu kara-age, so deep-fried fugu chunks.
The flavour of fugu is very refined, and difficult to 'get'.
By the way, I have no idea
if the faint feeling of numbness on my tongue
is actually happening, or just the placebo effect
Best chefs apparently are able to preserve
just the tiniest bit of toxin in the meal,
just enough for you to taste it.

Best sake I've ever tried
smells like crystal clear water,
no hint of alcohol of whatsoever.
And here we have this restaurant's specialty
a cup of hot sake - and I mean really, burning hot
- with dried-out fugu fins.
A really good combination
the fugu flavour nicely compliments the taste of sake.
Here we have a sort of, fugu barbecue
that's a DIY affair, Japanese-style
You've got to be careful with the gristle,
work your way around it.
Mmm, fantastic stuff, absolutely ace.
This here is a hotpot, so called nabe, with fugu of course.

The way it works is, you place fish chunks
and vegetables in boling water.
We're having a 'deluxe' version of the hotpot,
meaning the chunks of fish come with actual fishbones.
The taste reminds me of carp a little bit.
Nothing goes to waste in Japan,
so when you order a full fugu dinner,
you get A FULL fugu dinner.
The thing in front of me is supposed to be
one of the most extreme things one could eat in Japan,
from a Western point of view that is.
It's called shirako, so, uh
a male version of caviar, I'm guessing?
Fish milt to put it mildly.
Which, let's face it, is basically fish sperm.
Soo, uh...
Cheers.
Like... It's good, it really is.
Just so damn weird I can't even...
I mean, being aware of the fact that you've just eaten fish sperm...
Meanwhile the fish stock that's left over from our hotpot
has been transformed into a rice porridge.
I mean, 'rice porridge' - that's a dumb thing to say.
What happened was basically, a lady came over,
added some rice and eggs,
the whole ceremony was quite mesmerizing
after seasoning she tried it in her own little bowl
to check if it tasted right,
and gave some to Yuen to try as well.
Makes you think of somelier service in a restaurant, like...
Egg congealed in fugu fish stock, with rice
Good stuff, like everything tonight - very, very refined flavours
Taste for fugu has to be acquired, I think
I'm not quite there yet myself
but all the Japanese people we spoke to
claim that this stuff's absolutely delicious and they love it.
You need to develop a distinctive palate to appreciate fugu.
It's definitely an experience,
not something you'd eat on a daily, or even weekly basis.
More of a 'special treat' type of thing.
What you guys saw tonight was not only the fugu fish,
but also a typically Japanese dinner
carried out in a way that has a sort of a narrative to it,
where one plate leads to another.
Which, in turn, leads us to the topic of kaiseki,
a traditional, elaborate, multi-course Japanese dinner experience,
but that deserves a seperate video.
All in all: fugu didn't kill us,
so: toxin owning - check
fish sperm eating - check.
What's left is a congratulatory ice-cream portion
with a predictable, ordinary nougat flavour
Thanks for watching! Make sure you don't miss the new videos
we'll be posting on youtube.com/wybuchajacebeczki

title: Śmiercionośna ryba Fugu i rybie nasienie [Tokyo] / Fugu fish dinner & shirako w/ English subtitles
